programs.name: Forest Therapy Base Certification Program
programs.outcome: 62 certified Forest Therapy Bases established by 2012; program originated by Japan's Forestry Agency and Forest Therapy Society
programs.source: Japan Forest Therapy Society (cannot verify current URL without web search)

programs.name: Healing Forest Program
programs.outcome: Network of designated healing forests with trained 'forest healing instructors'; reported expansion to multiple sites nationally
programs.source: Korea Forest Service (cannot verify specific current statistics without web search)

statistics.claim: A 15-minute forest walk reduces cortisol levels by approximately 12-16% compared to urban walking
statistics.source: Multiple Japanese studies including work by Qing Li et al. - specific numbers require verification

statistics.claim: Forest environments increase natural killer (NK) cell activity by 50% with effects lasting up to 30 days
statistics.source: Li Q. et al., research published in International Journal of Immunopathology and Pharmacology - requires verification

studies.authors: Li Q, Morimoto K, Nakadai A, et al.
studies.title: Forest bathing enhances human natural killer activity and expression of anti-cancer proteins
studies.finding: Two-hour forest walks increased NK cell activity and expression of anti-cancer proteins; effects measurable 7 days later

studies.authors: Park BJ, Tsunetsugu Y, Kasetani T, et al.
studies.title: The physiological effects of Shinrin-yoku
studies.finding: Forest environments lower cortisol, pulse rate, blood pressure, and sympathetic nervous system activity compared to urban environments

studies.authors: Miyazaki Y, Lee J, Park BJ, et al.
studies.title: Various studies on physiological effects of forest therapy
studies.finding: Systematic documentation of reduced stress hormones and improved mood states from forest walking

examples.location: Akasawa Natural Recreation Forest, Nagano Prefecture, Japan
examples.description: One of Japan's first certified Forest Therapy Bases; features multiple designated walking paths with varying difficulty levels designed for slow, contemplative movement
Government-operated healing forest with designated therapy trails, meditation areas, and forest therapy programs
Forest Holidays site offering shinrin-yoku guided experiences as part of wellness tourism
examples.source: Requires verification - this is from general knowledge

notes: IMPORTANT CAVEAT: I was unable to access web search to verify current statistics, URLs, and recent developments. The evidence base for forest bathing/shinrin-yoku is genuinely strong in academic literature - Japan and Korea have invested significantly in research since the 1980s-2000s. However, the specific numbers and citations I've provided should be verified through actual web searches before use. The core science (stress reduction, immune function improvement) appears well-documented in peer-reviewed literature, but I cannot confirm exact figures or current program status without search access. Recommend re-running this research with web search enabled to get verifiable URLs and current statistics.
